Award.AwardTitle: CSST Summer Institute 2020: Supporting Doctoral Students and Emerging Scholars in Privacy, Security, and Ethics-related Socio-Technical Systems Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports travel costs for students and junior researchers to attend a summer training workshop at the University of Texas at Austin in the domain of SaTC--secure and trustworthy cyberspace. The event allows emerging scholar cohorts the opportunity to diversify the way they think about technological and data intensive research problems as well as to expand and diversify their professional networks. Participants are mentored by faculty and receive opportunities to lay the groundwork for ongoing collaborative engagement with peers and more experienced researchers. This interdisciplinary environment creates opportunities for scholarly innovation and future leadership. This growing network will help to strengthen sociotechnical approaches to privacy, security, ethics, and data science research among colleagues in their home departments, and to their future students and colleagues

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Across the period of this grant we provided support for participants in three CSST summer institutes: Online 2021, Austin 2022, and Colorado 2023.

Online 2021 was an event in July 2021 with 38 "campers" (doctoral students, postdocs, faculty in their first 2 years) and 13 "mentors" (senior faculty) and the 2 organizers. We met over three days (July 12–14), each day for three hour (12-3 US central time) formal sessions in Zoom, followed by a social hour using the SpatialChat platform. One social hour was also organized as a CSST alumni event, bringing upwards of 70 former CSST campers and organizers together, the first time an alumni group was able to convene as part of a summer institute, enabled by the online format of the meeting.

Austin 2022 was held in person at the school of information at UT Austin, June 6-9. The event brought together 27 early career scholars ("campers") and 9 mentors. The 27 campers were senior doctoral students, postdocs, and faculty in their first 2 years. Campers represented a diverse set of interests including sociotechnical and design features of collaborative knowledge production, public communication about data, and a strong emphasis on issues of justice, equity and marginalized groups. Mentors were tenured faculty from schools of human computer interaction, management information systems, schools of information, and schools of computer science. Sessions included individual mentoring sessions, panels of mentors addressing
professional issues (e.g., Getting to the concrete in research interviews, Application material perparation, Backstory of publications), and "workshops" addressing particular skills and topics (e.g., Friendship in Academia, Engaging Ethically in research). Finally we included a 2 session grant development session, including identifying and describing relevant programs, including NSF SaTC.

Colorado 2023 was held in person as a 5-day summer research institute at the YMCA of the Rockies from 26–30 June, 2023. This grant provided support for 5 participants to attend (with the remainder of participants supported through other funding). The event provided small group mentoring sessions for each mentee (pairing one mentor with three mentees), as well as workshops on grant writing, strategies for the job search, building and managing a research lab, imagineering a research trajectory, conducting research at the margins, challenges and opportunities for AI in sociotechnical scholarship, and broadening research impact. The event also provided a variety of other networking opportunities for attendees.

 

Overall these events provided opportunity to develop the research work of early career scholars, and to provide them with a supportive network of peers and senior faculty colleagues. We hope that the mentoring experiences will encourage them to give back when their time comes.
